title: Strings
text:
Given two strings A and B, we define the operator ĉ on {A, B} for string C as C ĉ {A, B}.if length(A) < length(C) < length(B), then C satisfies the above operator.
else
      if length(A)=length(C), then C must be lexicographically greater than A.
      if length(B)=length(C), then C must be lexicographically smaller than B.InputGiven two strings A and B with length(A) <= length(B) <= 6.  A and B can contain any characters between A and J (capital letters).OutputPrint the number of strings satisfying the above criteria.
C must also satisfy criteria of A and B. Any two adjacent
characters in string C may neither be the same nor consecutive (i.e. the absolute difference between the ASCII values of adjacent characters is greater than 1).ExampleInput:A J
AA BCD
ABC DEFGOutput:8
129
1770
sample_input:
if length(A) < length(C) < length(B), then C satisfies the above operator.
else
      if length(A)=length(C), then C must be lexicographically greater than A.
      if length(B)=length(C), then C must be lexicographically smaller than B.
sample_output:
Input:A J
AA BCD
ABC DEFGOutput:8
129
1770

test_cases.input:
if length(A) < length(C) < length(B), then C satisfies the above operator.
else
      if length(A)=length(C), then C must be lexicographically greater than A.
      if length(B)=length(C), then C must be lexicographically smaller than B.

A J
AA BCD
ABC DEFG
